subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class

messageBody:
On 7/23/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
>
> No, it doesn't. The method can either be reached through the public API
> (in which case test that) or it can be eliminated. There's no reason you
> have to invoke a method directly to test it.


It's still better if you do. It's easier to locate an error if the method
that caused it is directly above it on the stack trace rather than if you
have three potential culprits.

Here is a quick example: I once presented a list in a certain order in
HTML, and this order suddenly started being wrong. I traced this error all
the way down to the sorting routine, which was private and not tested. If I
had a unit test for that private method, I would have been able to pinpoint
the problem right away instead of wasting my time in the code that generates
the HTML.

Back to the original question. You have two options:

- You absolutely want to keep that method private, and in this case,
you should probably invoke it via reflection (see setAccessible(true)).

- You can relax the visibility of this method, in which case I suggest
making it package protected and then put your test in the same package (it
can still be in a separate source folder).

I recommend the latter approach...

--
